sp.p: The Earl of Warwick, and my Lord Mohun, as they turned up the Lane, asked Mr. Coote, Whither he vvas going? and vvhen he ſaid to Leiceſterfields, they deſired him to let it alone till to morrovv; and my Lord Mohun ſaid he ſhould go home vvith him; but the other bid us go on, and ſaid he vvould not go to his Lodgings, but, that they vvould make an end of it that night; Still they called to him again, Dear Coote let's ſpeak a Word vvith you, and as the Chairs came to the Back-Door of the Croſs-Keys Tavern, there they ſtood all of a-breaſt, and they both of them ſpoke to him, and ſtood a pretty vvhile there, and in the mean time 3 Chairs paſſed by on the other ſide, he Commanded us to take up, and carry him avvay to Leiceſter-fields immediately, and overtake the other Chairs, or he vvould run one of us into the Body.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: Would your Lordſhip ask him any more Queſtions?

sp.speaker: E. of Warrwick.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, I obſerve, he ſays they Diſcourſed ſome time together while they ſtopped in St. Martins-Lane, I deſire that he may be asked, whether he can toll what that Diſcourſe was?

sp.speaker: Browne.
sp.p: I could not well hear, they Whiſpered together, but I could hear my Lord Mohun, and my Lord of Warwick, deſire Capt. Coote to go home, and let the Buſineſs alone till another time.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: I deſire he may Explain himſelf, what that Buſineſs was that they would have put off till to morrow?

sp.speaker: Browne.
sp.p: I know not what it was, I heard of no Anger betwixt them, but they were as good Friends for any thing I know to the contrary, as ever they were in their Lives, or as ever I ſee any Men.

sp.speaker: L. Jeffereys.
sp.p: He ſays there were Two went into Chairs at the Door of the Houſe, and afterwards went out again, and went into the Houſe, and there was Diſcourſe at the Bar of the Houſe, I would deſire to know what that was?

sp.speaker: Browne.
sp.p: I did not hear the Diſcourſe that was in the Houſe, I was at the Door of the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Our next Witneſs is William Crippes.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: What do you ask this Man, Mr. Attorney?

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray will you give my Lords here an Account who you carried to Leiceſter-fields the 29th or 30th of October, and what happened in your knowledge at that time?

sp.speaker: Crippes.
sp.p:
Capt. Coote was the firſt Man that went into the Chair when we came to the Greyhound Tavern, afterwards he came out again, and when we took him up the ſecond time he was the firſt Man that ſet out, and he bid us carry him to Leiceſter-fields, and when we came to the Corner of St. Martins-Lane, we turned up that way; and my Lord of Warwick, and my Lord Mohun, called to us, being in Chairs behind, to know whither we were going, and deſired to ſpeak with Capt. Coote, and he ſaid he was going to Leiceſter-fields; and when they asked, what to do? he ſaid, To end the Buſineſs; They deſired him to put it off till to morrow; and while they were Diſcourſing about it in St. Martins-Lane, there paſſed by other 3 Chairs, which when Capt. Coote ſaw, he bid us take up and overtake them, and go faſter, or he would run one of
us into the Body; So we went on, and at the lower end of Leiceſter-fields we ſet him dovvn; and the other Two Gentlemen, my Lord Warwick, and my Lord Mohun, were there ſet down, and went Lovingly together, for any thing that I ſaw, up the Pavement of the Square, towards the upper end; and in a little time we heard a Noiſe of Calling for Chairs towards the upper end, and when we came there with the Chair, we were bid to lift over the Chair within the Rails, and when we ſaid it was hard to be done, they inſiſted upon it, and we did come in, and when we came there we ſaw Two Gentlemen holding up Capt. Coote, and would have had us taken him into the Chair; We ſaw there was a great deal of Blood, but I never heard how it came, and they would have had us carried him to a French Surgeon's, and proffered any Money.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to know, who they were that deſired him to be carried to the Surgeon?

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: You hear the Queſtion, What ſay you?

sp.speaker: Crippes.
sp.p: I cannot tell, my Lord, one of them had ſomething of Lace upon him, but it was ſo dark that I could hardly ſee my Hand, and therefore I cannot tell who they were; and when there was an Objection made, that the Chairs would be ſpoiled, they ſaid we need not queſtion our Chair, they would give us 100 l Security to anſwer any Damages, if we would but carry him; ſo we endeavoured to put him into the Chair, but could not; and ſo we called out to the Watch, to have had ſome help, but they ſaid it was none of their Ward, and ſo they would not come to us; ſo the Gentlemen went away; and we left them, and went and called a Chirurgeon, who when he came ſaid, he was a Dead Man, and we were ſecured till the next day.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, I deſire he may be asked, Were there not other Chairs in that place at that time?

sp.speaker: Crippes.
sp.p: There was one in the Field beſides, and no more that I could ſee, they all went away but us Two.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What diſtance of time was there between their ſetting down in Leiceſter-fields, and their Calling the Chairs again?

sp.speaker: Crippes.
sp.p: Not a quarter of an hour.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What became of the 3 Chairs that paſſed by you in St. Martins-Lane?

sp.speaker: Crippes.
sp.p: They got before us, but what became of them afterwards I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did they come from the ſame place, the Tavern in the Strand that you were at?

sp.speaker: Crippes.
sp.p: Yes, I believe they did, my Lord, for Capt. Coote bid us follow them, and threatned us if we did not make greater haſte.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Do you know my Lord of Warwick?

sp.speaker: Crippes.
sp.p: Yes, he had Whitiſh Cloaths on, and none but he had ſuch Cloaths on as thoſe were.

sp.speaker: L. H. S.
sp.p: Will your Lordſhip ask this Witneſs any Queſtions?

sp.speaker: E. of Warwick.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire he may be asked, Whether I did not bid him ſtop? And, Whether I did not ſay, they ſhould not go to Quarrel that night?

sp.speaker: Crippes.
sp.p: Yes, both he and my Lord Mohun would not have had Captain Coote gone any where, but home to his Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to know of him, directly and down-right, Whether my Lord of Warwick was not one of them that held him when he was within the Rails in the Fields?

sp.speaker: Crippes.
sp.p: No, he was not, he was neither of them, for the one of them was too big for him, and the other was too little for my Lord Mohun?

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Now we ſhall Call the Chairman that carried the Earl of Warwick into Leiceſter-fields. James Crattle.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Will you tell my Lords what you know of any Perſon that you carried the 29th or 30th of October laſt from the Greyhound Tavern in the Strand, and who it was, and whither you carried him?

sp.speaker: Crattle.
sp.p: I was going along Charing-Croſs between One and two in the morning the 20th of October laſt, and I heard a Chair called for at Lockets a • the Dog-Tavern, and thither I and my Partner went, and we took up the Gentleman, and carried him to Leiceſter-fields.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Who was that Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Crattle.
sp.p: It was my Lord of Warwick.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What time of night do you ſay it was?

sp.speaker: Crattle.
sp.p: It was about One or two in the morning.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What day of the Week was it?

sp.speaker: Crattle.
sp.p: It was Saturday night and Sunday morning.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Whither did you carry him?

sp.speaker: Crattle.
sp.p: Into Greenſtreet, towards the lower end of Leiceſter Square.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What Chairs were there more there?

sp.speaker: Crattle.
sp.p: There was one that Capt. Coote was in, and another that my Lord Mohun was in, and we w • nt away all together.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Were there no other Chairs?

sp.speaker: Crattle.
sp.p: I did not know who went in the other Chairs, but there were 3 other Chairs that paſſed by us at St. Martins-Lane, and we followed after them to Leiceſter-fields.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray what became of you after you had ſet down your Fare?

sp.speaker: Crattle.
sp.p: We were Diſcharged and Paid, the other 3 went up towards my Lord of Leiceſter's, but we were coming away, and in a little time we heard the Noiſe of calling Chairs, Chairs, again, and there were Two Chairs did come up, Thomas Browne's and ours; My Lord of Warwick called our Chair, and we took him into it, and he bid us carry him to the Bagnic in Longacre, and when we came there we knocked at the Door, and his Hand was bloody, and he asked us if we had any Handkerchief to bind up his Hand.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Was there any other Chairs at the Door of the Bagnio, at the ſame time when you came there?

sp.speaker: Crattle.
sp.p: Yes, there was another Chair there at the Door at the ſame time, and we ſet down both together.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, Whence came that Chair?

sp.speaker: Crattle.
sp.p: Indeed I do not know.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Who were the Chairmen that carried that Chair?

sp.speaker: Crattle.
sp.p: Indeed my Lord Mohun, and my Lord Warwick, were the only Perſons that I knew of all the Company.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What ſort of Gentleman was the other that went out of the other Chair into the Houſe?

sp.speaker: Crattle.
sp.p: He was a pretty tall Man; when he was in we went away; I only can ſay I ſaw my Lord of Warwick go into the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did you take any notice of any Sword that my Lord of Warwick had in his Hand at that time?

sp.speaker: Crattle.
sp.p: No, I cannot ſay I did take any notice of any Sword, only that there was a Handkerchief deſired.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, Did you hear no Noiſe at all in the Field, till you heard Chairs called for again?

sp.speaker: Crattle.
sp.p: No, I cannot ſay I heard any Noiſe in the Field.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did you apprehend there vvas any Fighting?

sp.speaker: Crattle.
sp.p: No, I knevv nothing at all of it, but upon the calling of Chairs again, and my Lord Warwick coming along, vve tock him in, and he bid us go to the Bagnio, and thither vve vvent.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, vve have done vvith this Witneſs.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: My Lord Warwick, vvill you ask this Witneſs any Queſtions?

sp.speaker: E. of Warwick.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Then, my Lord, our next Witneſs is John Gibſon, he vvas another of thoſe Chairmen that carried my Lord of Warwick to the Bagnio aftervvards. Pray, Will you give my Lords an Account vvhat you knovv, vvho you carried the 29th and 30th of October laſt, and vvhither you carried them?

sp.speaker: Gibſon.
sp.p: My Lord, I was at Charing-Croſs with my Partner the 29th of October laſt, at night, and about One or two a Clock in the morning Chairs were called for to the Greyhound-Tavern in the Strand, and when we came there, my Lord of Warwick, my Lord Mohun, and Mr. Coote, got into the 3 firſt Chairs, and we got my Lord Warwick into our Chair, and when we had him there we were bid to go towards Leiceſter-fields, as I apprehended, for thither the Chairs that went firſt was to go, and indeed my Lord Mohun, and my Lord Warwick, did call to ſtop at the end of St. Martins-Lane, and asked Mr. Coote whither he was going? and he ſaid he was going to make an end of the Buſineſs, and they ſaid it ſhould not be to night, but preſently after 3 other Chairs coming along, and paſſing before us, the Chair that Capt. Coote was in was bid to go on, and we were ordered to follow, which was done accordingly; Juſt at the Turning of Greenſtreet we ſet down our 3 Chairs, and having had 3 Shillings given us, we were bid to go about our buſineſs; and, I think, juſt about the Turning of Greenſtreet end we ſtayed till there came another Chair again, and we and the other Chair upon my Lord Warwick's coming into us, went away from thence, and carried him to the Bagnio in Longacre.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: You talk of another Chair, pray, Whoſe Chair was that?

sp.speaker: Gibſon.
sp.p: There was another Chair that was got there juſt before us, but indeed I do not know whoſe it was, nor indeed can I ſay vvho it vvas that vvas in it, but this I am ſure vve vvent to the ſame place, and vve met and lit juſt at the ſame time, and my Lord of Warwick asked for a Handkerchief to bind about his Hand, vvhich vvas bloody, vvich vvas given him.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did you not knovv vvho vvas in the other Chair at that time?

sp.speaker: Gibſon.
sp.p: No, indeed, I did not knovv, I vvill aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, Did you not knovv vvhere that other Chair took the other Gentleman up?

sp.speaker: Gibſon.
sp.p: No, indeed Sir, I do not.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, What time of the Night vvas it?

sp.speaker: Gibſon.
sp.p: It vvas betvveen One and tvvo of the Clock in the Morning.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: You talk of his Hand being hurt, and that he called for a Handkerchief, Did you ſee his Hand bleed? and, pray, in vvhat nature vvas his Wound?

sp.speaker: Gibſon.
sp.p: My Lord, all I can ſay is, there vvas Blood, and he vvanted a Handkerchief, and had one, for he ſaid his Hand was hurt, but in truth I did not take any notice what that hurt was, I did not ſee it, if my Partner took notice of it, ſo, but elſe I can ſay nothing to it, but the Handkerchief was afterwards asked again, and could not be had.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: Would my Lord of Warwick ask this Witneſs any Queſtions?

sp.speaker: E. of Warwick.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Then, my Lord, our next Witneſſes are Robert, Applegate, and Peter Catro, who will give your Lordſhip an Account who they carried at this time.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: Whom do you call firſt?

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: What Queſtions do you ask him, Mr. Attorney?

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: I deſire that he would acquaint your Lordſhip, what he knows of what paſſed at the Greyhound-Tavern in the Strand the 29th of October laſt, whom he carried, and whither he carried them?

sp.speaker: Applegate.
sp.p: My Lord, about One or two a Clock in the morning, a Sunday morning, the 29th or 30th of October laſt I was going home with my Partner and my Chair, and I heard them calling at the Greyhound Tavern in the Strand, Mr. Lockett's, for Coaches and Chairs, there was no Coach to be had that could be heard of, but coming up to the Door they ſaid they wanted 6 Chairs, and when we were there at the Door, there came out firſt my Lord Warwick, Capt. Coote, and my Lord Mohun, Capt. Coote got into the firſt Chair, and what Directions he gave them I cannot tell; My Lord of Warwick got into the next, and into ours, which was the third, my Lord Mohun came in, and bid us take him up and carry him towards Weſtminſter, and he ordered us to follow the Chairs before; Juſt as they turned at St. Martins-Lane, my Lord Mohun called out, and deſired to ſtop, and at the Croſs-Keys Tavern Back Door a • the 3 Chairs came up together, and then my Lord of Warwick, and Capt. Coote, and my Lord Mohun talked together, and I could hear my Lord Mohun and my Lord of Warwick deſire Capt. Coote to defer it, and put it by till another day; what it was, indeed I cannot tell: but while they were talking there, Three Chairs more came up on the other ſide of the way, and Capt. Coote would needs go forward, and my Lord Mohun and my Lord of Warwick went with him, and ſo they were all ſet down at the lower end of Leiceſter-fields at Green-ſtreet end. But in truth I did not ſee where the other Three Chairs ſet down thoſe they carried.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What then hapned afterwards, Can you tell?

sp.speaker: Appleby.
sp.p: I cannot tell whether I had Lighted my Pipe, or juſt Lighting it, when I heard Chairs called again, upon which we run up with our Chair towards the upper end of the Fields, and there I did ſee my Lord of Warwick within the Rails, vvho bid us put over our Chair into the Fields, but vve told him if vve did, vve could not get it over again, and ſo vve vvent vvith our Chair to the corner of the Fields, and vvhen vve came there, there came out Capt. French, vvho bid us open our Chair, and let him in, for he did believe he vvas a Dead Man; and upon that vve did take him in, and he bid us carry him vvith all the ſpeed we could to the Bagnio in Long-Acre, and my Lord of Warwick got into another Chair behind, ſo vvent to Lang-Acre, and vvhen vve came to the Door of the Bagnio, and Capt. French came out of the Chair, he vvas ſo vveak that he fell dovvn upon his Knees; and vvhen he came out, I asked vvho ſhould Pay me, and deſired to be Diſcharged, and the Earl of Warwick ſaid, Damn ye, Call for your Money to Morrovv, ſo they both vvent in at the Bagnio Door together.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray vvho called for the Chair firſt, Capt. French, or my Lord of Warwick in the Fields.

sp.speaker: Applegate.
sp.p: I cannot tell, but vvhen I brought up my Chair, I firſt ſavv my Lord of Warwick, and he vvould have had me lifted the Chair over the Rails, and I told him vve could not get it over again, and ſo vvent up to the upper end of the Fields.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: If you firſt ſpoke vvith my Lord of Warwick, Why did you not Carry my Lord of Warwick?

sp.speaker: Applegate.
sp.p: Indeed I cannot tell, but I ſuppoſe it vvas becauſe he did not come ſo ſoon out of the Fields as Capt. French, or did not come the ſame vvay.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray do you remember any thing that happened juſt at their carrying Capt. French avvay?

sp.speaker: Applegate.
sp.p: Before he went into the Chair he ſtopped, and would have pulled off his Cloaths, but we would not let him.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did you ſee any Sword Capt. French had?

sp.speaker: Applegate.
sp.p: I did ſee no Sword that I can ſay directly vvas a Svvord, but Capt. French had ſomething in his hand, but vvhat it vvas I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What vvas it that he ſaid to you, vvhen he firſt vvent into the Chair?

sp.speaker: Applegate.
sp.p: He deſired to be carried to the Bagnio, for he ſaid he believed he vvas a dead Man.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, Friend, recollect your ſelf, if you heard him ſay any thing at all vvhen he firſt vvent into the Chair at the Greybound Tavern.?

sp.speaker: Applegate.
sp.p: I did not hear him mention any thing at all,

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray vvhat did you hear my Lord of Warwick ſay at that time?

sp.speaker: Applegate,
sp.p: Truly I cannot ſay I heard him mention any thing at all neither, but I did hear my Lord Mohun ſay, vvhen he could not prevail in St Martins-Lane vvith Capt. Coote to go home, that if they did go he vvould go and ſee it.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: If They did go, vvho did he mean by They?

sp.speaker: Applegate.
sp.p: My Lord Warwick and Capt. Coote that vvere in the other Chairs, there vvas no body elſe to ſpeak to.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Was there any talk of Fighting or Quarrelling?

sp.speaker: Applegate.
sp.p: No indeed, I do not knovv of any difference there vvas betvveen them.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: My Lord Warwick, Will your Lordſhip ask this Witneſs any Queſtions?

sp.speaker: E. of War.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire he may be asked, Whether I did not endeavour to put off the going into Leiceſter Fields, and to have all things let alone till to Morrovv.

sp.speaker: Applegate.
sp.p: My Lord, I cannot ſay any thing of that, but I did hear my Lord Mohun beg heartily of Capt. Coote to go home, and le • t the buſineſs alone till another time; and indeed I think I never heard a Man beg more hearty for an Alms at a Door, than he did, that they might not go into the Fields then, but I cannot ſay that I heard any thing that my Lord of Warwick ſaid about it.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: Will your Lordſhip ask him any other Queſtions?

sp.speaker: E. of War.
sp.p: No my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: Did my Lord Warwick expreſs any Inclination to go on.

sp.speaker: Applegate.
sp.p: Indeed I know not any thing one way nor other.

sp.speaker: L. Jeffereys.
sp.p: My Lords, If I am not miſtaken he did ſay, that he did not ſee any thing of Inclination in my Lord of Warwick to go on; but I deſire if your Lordſhips pleaſe that he may be asked this Queſtion, Whether he did ſee any thing in my Lord of Warwick that ſhewed any Inclination to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Applegate.
sp.p: All that I can ſay is, I heard my Lord Mohun ſay, Pray let's go home and lie all together, and let us put off this buſineſs to another time; but indeed I do not remember that my Lord of Warwick ſaid one word of going any way backward or forward.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, who did my Lord Mohun ſpeak theſe words to?

sp.speaker: Applegate.
sp.p: My Lord Mohun ſpoke them to my Lord of Warwick and Capt. Coote both.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: Mr. Attorney, Who is your next Witneſs?

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: What do you ask him, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: He was the other Chair-man that carried my Lord Mohun, Pray will you give my Lords an account what you know paſſed at the time when you carried my Lord Mohun to Leiceſter-fields?

sp.speaker: Catro.
sp.p:
I and my Fellow carried my Lord Mohun from the Greyhound Tavern in the Strand, till we came to the turning up of St. Martins-Lane, where my Lord Mohun deſired that our Three Chairs might ſtop, and that they might go down to Weſtminſter, and that my Lord Warwick and Capt. Coote would go thither, and he would wait upon them to their Lodging; Capt. Coote made Anſwer again ſomething, but what I cannot tell, and his Chair went on, and my
Lord Mohun did ſay, if they went forward he would follow them, and ſee what would come of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What did you ſee happen while you were in St. Martins Lane?

sp.speaker: Catro.
sp.p: There were other Three Chairs that went by while we ſtood at the Croſs-Keys Tavern Door, and Capt. Coote's Chair going forward, we follow'd and went to the end of Leiceſter-fields at Green-ſtreet end, and there all Three went out of their Chairs and walked up the paved Stones of the Square; my Lord of Warwick asked my Lord Mohun if he had any Silver, and Three Shillings were given for the Three Chairs, and they went from us, and bid us go about our buſineſs, and in a little while after we heard a noiſe from the upper end of the Fields calling Chairs again.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did you obſerve any thing of Quarrel or Difference between them, or any claſhing of Swords.

sp.speaker: Catro.
sp.p: Indeed I heard nothing of any Quarrel, for we were at the lower • nd of the Square, at Green-ſtreet end, and when we heard them call for Chairs again; we went up towards the upper end of the Fields, and when we came there we heard one bid us bring up the Chair over the Rails.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Who was that?

sp.speaker: Catro.
sp.p: Indeed my Lord I cannot tell, for I was behind the Chair, and could not ſee who it was, but we ſaying that we could not get it over again if we did; we went up to the upper end of the Fields, and there was Capt. French, I think it was, for I did not perfectly ſee him, being at the hind-part of the Chair, and we went on to the Bagnio in Long-Acre: and I did ſee my Lord Warwick come out of his Chair at the Bagnio Door, for there they were ſet down,

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: You ſay you ſaw my Lord of Warwick at the Bagnio Door; Did you ſee any Sword as my Lord of Warwick had, or Capt. French?

sp.speaker: Catro.
sp.p: No, I did not ſee any Sword at all of either of them.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What do you know of Capt. French his declaring he was wounded.

sp.speaker: Catro.
sp.p: I think it was either when he went into the Chair, or in Newport-ſtreet end he called out to have the Chair opened, for ſays he I think I am a dead Man, and would have pulled off his Cloaths; and when we were at the Bagnio Door we tarryed a pretty while till they got them up to let them in, and asking if we ſhould wait, my Lord of Warwick bid us come to that Houſe to Morrow Morning for our Money, and they went in together into the Houſe, but I never heard any one word of Quarrel or Diſſatisfaction paſſed betweeen them.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: This Witneſs ſpeaks to the ſame purpoſe as the other did, and I think we need not trouble your Lordſhip any further as to that.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: Would my Lord Warwick ask him any Queſtions?

sp.speaker: E. of War.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Then our next Witneſs is one John Palmer.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray will you give my Lords an Account who it was you did carry in your Chair the 29th, or 30th. of October laſt, and whither you carry'd him?

sp.speaker: Palmer.
sp.p: About one a Clock in the Morning, the 30th of October, we were called to the Greyhound Tavern in the Strand to Mr. Lockett's, and there we took up a Gentleman, one Captain French.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Whither did you carry him?

sp.speaker: Palmer.
sp.p: He bid us go to Leiceſter-fields.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What did he particularly ſay to you?

sp.speaker: Palmer.
sp.p: There were three other Chairs that were juſt gone before from the ſame Door, and he bid us get before all thoſe Chairs, and juſt as we came to St. Martins-lane end, we ſaw there were three other Chairs ſet down before us over-againſt the Croſs-Keys Tavern Back-Door.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Well, what did you do then?

sp.speaker: Palmer.
sp.p: So we went before according as we were bid unto Leiceſter-fields, and at the upper-end of the Fields by Leioeſter-houſe we opened the Door, and Captain French came out, and he gave us a Shilling, and we went away about our Buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Were there any more Chairs there that went with you?

sp.speaker: Palmer.
sp.p: There were two more Chairs that ſet down two other Gentlemen by Leiceſter-houſe, and we came away when we were paid; that is all I know.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did you ſee any other Chairs beſides your three when you came down again, or any other Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Palmer.
sp.p: We did ſee ſome Gentlemen walking up about the middle of the Square when we came down, but we made what haſt we could away home, it being late, and Sunday Morning.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did you obſerve any Fighting vvhen you vvere in the Field?

sp.speaker: Palmer.
sp.p: I did not hear or diſcern any Fighting vvhile I vvas there.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did you hear of any Quarrel, or any thing betvveen any of them and vvhom before?

sp.speaker: Palmer.
sp.p: No, I did not knovv of any Quarrel, or hear of any thing at all I do aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: All that he ſays then, my Lord, is, That he carried Capt. French to the upper-end of Leiceſter-Fields, and there he left him.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: Would my Lord Warwick ask this Witneſs any Queſtions?

sp.speaker: E. of Warw.
sp.p: I deſire he may be asked, Whether he knows who were in the Chairs that were in St. Martins-Lane when they paſſed by?

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: You hear the Queſtion, What ſay you to it?

sp.speaker: Palmer.
sp.p: There were three Chairs, but who they were that were in them I cannot tell directly but as they ſaid when they ſet them down at Leiceſter-Fields they were my Lord Warwick, my Lord Mohun, and Mr. Coote.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Who was it that ſaid ſo?

sp.speaker: Palmer.
sp.p: Some of the other Chairmen when I came by.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: Mr. Attorney, Who is your next Witneſs?

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: We ſhall call next the Chairmen that carried Mr. Dockwra and Mr. James: Call Jackson the Chairman.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: This Man carried Captain James: Pray acquaint my Lords, Who you did take up at Lockett's in the Strand on the 29th or 30th of October laſt, and vvhither you carried him?

sp.speaker: Jackson.
sp.p: I carried Captain James from Lockett's in the Strand into Leiceſterfields.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Hovv many Chairs vvere you that vvent?

sp.speaker: Jackson.
sp.p: There vvere tvvo more that vvent vvhen I vvent, there vvere ſix in all that took up Gentlemen there, and vve vvere the laſt but one.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Can you tell vvho vvere in the other three firſt Chairs?

sp.speaker: Jackson.
sp.p: I do not knovv vvho vvere in the other Chairs, but I heard my Lord Mohun at the Door of the Houſe deſire, That the Buſineſs might be deferred till to morrovv Morning: There vvere ſix Gentlemen at the Door, but truly vvho they all vvere I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Who did my Lord Mohun ſpeak that to?

sp.speaker: Jackson.
sp.p: Indeed I do not knovv vvho he ſpoke it to.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What Anſvver vvas made to my Lord Mohun?

sp.speaker: Jackson.
sp.p:
Truly there vvas no Anſvver that I heard, but vve all vvent avvay ſoon after that, and we were bid to go to Leiceſter-fields to follow the other Chairs, and when we came to the other end of Leiceſter-fields, we ſet down Captain James by the Standard Tavern, and he gave us a Shilling and bid us go our ways; ſo we went our way, and I heard nothing afterwards but came away down the Fields, and there were three Chairs that ſtood at the bottom of the Fields, and we asked them, What they ſtayed there for? And they ſaid, To ſill a Pipe of Tobacco: And preſently after we heard Call Chairs again; but it
was late, and it was Sunday Morning, and my Partner ſaid, Let us go away home and we did ſo, we went directly home.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did you carry no body back?

sp.speaker: Jackson.
sp.p: No, we carried no body back.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, we have done with this Witneſs, our next Witneſs is one Richard Edwards, and he was one of the Chairmen that carried Mr. Dockwra.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray will you acquaint my Lords, Whether you carried any body from Lockett's the 29th of October, and who it was, and whither you • arried him?

sp.speaker: Edwards.
sp.p:
I do not know who I carried, but they were calling Coaches at 〈◊〉
Greyhound Tavern in the Strand, and no Coaches coming, they called for Chairs and ſo our Chair was brought up.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: When you came there, who did you ſee there?

sp.speaker: Edwards.
sp.p: Indeed I did not know my Lord of Warwick, nor my Lord Mohun, nor any of them.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Well, what do you know? Tell my Lords what happened.

sp.speaker: Edwards.
sp.p: When we were there, there went Two into two Chairs, and my Lord Mo • un ſaid, or another Gentleman, I cannot tell which, that the Chairs ſhould not go away, that they would kill any Man that ſhould go away, and they went out of the Chairs, and went into the Houſe again.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: And what happen'd after they went into the Houſe again?

sp.speaker: Edwards.
sp.p: After they went out of the Chairs into the Houſe again, as I was told, my Lord of Warwick, my Lord Mohun, and Mr. Coote, went into Three Chairs, and went away from the Door, and there were three Chairs of us that went laſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Whither did you go with your Chair?

sp.speaker: Edwards.
sp.p: We went to the Standard Tavern at the end of Leiceſter Fields, and when we came to the Tavern Door, we asked him if we ſhould knock at the Door, he ſaid no, but he gave us a Shilling and bid us go about our buſineſs, and ſo we did, for we went ſheer away to Charing-Croſs.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray can you tell who were in the other Chairs?

sp.speaker: Edwards.
sp.p: Truly I cannot tell any Man that was in our three Chairs, for I was the hind-Chairman, and did not know any of them.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to know what he means by hin'd-Chairman.

sp.speaker: Edwards.
sp.p: My Lord, Ours was the laſt Chair that went to Leiceſter Fields, and I was behind the Chair, and never could ſee any of them, it being ſo very dark after they took the Chairs, till we came to Charing-Croſs, at St. Martins-Lane, and then I could not ſee who the particular Perſons were that were in the Chairs; nor indeed, whoſe the Chairs were that carried them.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What Hour was it?

sp.speaker: Edwards
sp.p: It was very late, between One and Two in the Morning; it was paſt One before we were called out.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: You ſay you went to the upper end of Leiceſter-fields, with Two other Chairs; Pray did you ſee any other Chairs afterwards, and where?

sp.speaker: Edwards.
sp.p: We ſaw three Chairs at the lower end of the Square, as we came down by Green-ſtreet end, and we asked them, What they ſtayed there for, and they ſaid, to light a Pipe of Tobacco.

sp.speaker: M. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, Who had been carried in thoſe Chairs, Can you tell?

sp.speaker: Edwards.
sp.p: I did not ſee them ſet down any Body, and I cannot tell who they carried; and as for the Perſon that we carried, I did not ſo much as ſee him to know him, nor know who he was, but we went away as ſoon as ever we were paid.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: I have one Queſtion more to ask you; You ſay, That my Lord of Warwick at the Tavern Door bid you ſtay, and that none ſhould go away, and Swore he would run any Man through that ſhould go away.

sp.speaker: Edwards.
sp.p: It was my Lord Mohun; and then Two that had gone into the Chairs went into the Houſe again.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did not you ſay, that there was ſome talk of going to Weſtminſter?

sp.speaker: Edwards.
sp.p: My Lord Mohun did talk of going to Weſtminſter when they went into the Chairs the Second time, and I think I heard Mr. Coote ſay he would make an end of it then; and he would kill any Man that would not go forwards to Leiceſter-Fields.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: My Lord Warwick, will you ask this Witneſs any Queſtions?

sp.speaker: E. of Warw.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: Mr. Attorney, have you any more Evidence to call?

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, the next piece of Evidence that we ſhall apply our ſelves to, will be to what happened at the Bagnio in Long-Acre, after my Lord Warwick and Captain French came there: And the Witneſs that we ſhall call is Pomfret, and he is a Servant at the Bagnio in Long-Acre, and he will acquaint your Lordſhips who came thither the 30th of October laſt, and what happened there.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: What is his Name?

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: Is he Svvorn?

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: What is it that you Examine him about? What Queſtions do you ask him Mr. Attorney?

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Who name to his Maſter's Houſe; and at vvhat time they came.

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: My Lord, on Sunday the 30th of October laſt, between Two and Three in the Morning, there came to my Maſter's Door the Earl of War • ick, and knocked at the Door, and there was Captain French with him; and when they were let in, my Lord of Warwick told me that Capt. French was wounded, and he himſelf had a Wound, and he deſired that my Maſter might be called up for to Dreſs the Wounds; eſpecially, becauſe Captain French was very much wounded, which accordingly was done in about a quarter of an Hour after they were brought in.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did he deſire to be Concealed when he was come in?

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: Of whom do you ſpeak, Mr. Anorney.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord of Warwick.

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: He did deſire, that if any Body asked for him, it ſhould be ſaid he was not there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, in what Condition did my Lord of Warwick ſeem to be in at that time.

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: He ſeemed to be very much concerned at that time, and his Right Hand, in which he had his Sword, and which was drawn, was very much bloody.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was the Sword bloody that he had in his Hand?

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: The Blade was bloody; but whether it was all over bloody I cannot tell; there was beſides ſome blood upon the Shell, it was very near all over bloody, as I remember.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, Friend, Conſider what you Swore at the Coroner's Inqueſt about the Blood upon the Sword.

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: Indeed I cannot ſay it was bloody all along the Blade; but there was blood upon the Shell, and there was blood upon the Inſide, it was ſo to the beſt of my remembrance.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What Condition was Mr. French's Sword in.

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: He had a Drawn Sword in his Hand, but I did not perceive it had any Blood upon it: it was a large blade.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: How do you know what ſort of Sword Mr. French's was, and in what Condition it was?

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: He deſired me to take Notice of it next Morning, and I did ſo, and there was no Blood upon it.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: How came you to be deſired to take Notice of what paſſed there about the Swords?

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: My Lord, there was three of them the next Day, and one it was ſaid was Mr. Coote's, and another of them was my Lord of Warwick's, which I do believe was bloody from the Point upwards, very near, but I cannot direly ſay but that was afterwards.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Who brought in that Sword that you ſay was Mr. Coote's?

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: To the beſt of my Remembrance Captain Dockwra brought it in, it was almoſt half an Hour after my Lord Warwick and Captain French came into the Houſe, when they came thither.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: They, Who do you mean?

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: Captain James and he.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Were they let in preſently?

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: No. My Lord of Warwick had deſired that they might be private there; but when they knocked at the Door, my Lord of Warwick deſired to know who they were; and when it was underſtood that they were Mr. James and Mr. Dockwra, they were let in by my Lord's Order.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, which of all the Four brought in any Sword in a Scabbard?

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: It was Captain Dockwra.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, did they appear to be all of a Party?

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: They were glad to ſee one another; and they talked a pretty while together, but indeed I cannot ſay I heard what they talked.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, do you remember my Lord of Warwick's Sword, and what there was upon it?

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: It was a Steel Sword Water-Guilt, and as near as I can remember there was Blood upon it for the moſt part from the Point upward.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: And what did appear upon Mr. French's Sword?

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: There was Water and Dirt, but there was no Blood at all.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: How long did they ſtay there?

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: They all continued about half an Hour, and then went away, all but Mr. French, who ſtaid there.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What then became of the others?

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: Mr. James, and Mr. Dockwra, and my Lord of Warwick, went away, and my Lord of Warwick deſired particularly, that we would all take care of Mr. French, for he was his particular Friend, and Mr. French continued there till Sunday about One of the Clock.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Was there any Diſcourſe at that time about Mr. Coote?

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: Not that I heard of, one Word.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was there any notice taken of any Quarrel that happened between any Body, and who?

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: No, indeed, I did not hear them take notice of any Quarrel at all between any Body.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: You ſay Mr. French when he came into your Houſe was wounded, and there was Care particularly taken of him becauſe he was wounded.

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord of Warwick deſired to take Care of him.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Then pray, was there no Diſcourſe how he came to be wounded?

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: Indeed I do not know how he came to be wounded; nor did I hear one word of Diſcourſe about it, indeed I cannot ſay any thing who wounded him.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray will you recollect you ſelf, and tell my Lords what ſort of Handle had my Lord of Warwick's Sword when you ſaw it.

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: It had a Steel handle.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, can you tell whether the Shell was open or cloſe?

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: I cannot tell juſtly; I ſaw it, and that was all.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: If I apprehend you, you ſay my Lord had a Wound in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, he had ſo.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, in what Hand was it that he was wounded?

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: To the beſt of my remembrance it was in his Right Hand.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray did there appear much blood there?

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, indeed there did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Wright.
sp.p: You talk of Mr. James and Mr. Dockwra's Swords, pray in what Condition were they?

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: Mr. Dockwra's Sword by his ſide, and not drawn.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Wright.
sp.p: What did you obſerve of Captain James's Sword?

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: His Sword was Naked, and he had loſt his Scabbard; but how that came I cannot tell, and there was Dirt on one ſide of the Sword, and he ſaid he had left his Scabbard behind him.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Was there any Blood upon his Sword?

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: No, there was no Blood that I did ſee upon it.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, did you ſee any Blood upon Mr. Dockwra's Sword?

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: No, indeed, I did not ſee Mr. Dockwra's Sword, it was in the Scabbard by his ſide.

sp.speaker: D. of Leeds.
sp.p: My Lords, There has been notice here taken of ſeveral Swords that this Witneſs ſaw, and he takes ſo far notice of my Lord of Warwick's Sword, that he tells you what ſort of Hilt it had, and how it was bloody from the Point to the Hilt; I deſire he would give you an account of the Length and Breadth of the other Men's Swords, Mr. French, Mr. James, and Mr. Dockwra.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: You ſaid juſt now, that you took notice of my Lord of Warwick's Sword, that it was bloody from the Point to the Hilt, what ſort of Sword was it?

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: It was a pretty broad Sword.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: Did you take notice of the other Swords, what Breadth or Length they were of?

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Which was that Sword that was Dirty as you ſay?

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: That was Captain French's.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Was that a broad Sword or not?

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: No, it was not.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray was it over Night or next Morning that you ſaw the Swords?

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: It was in the Morning about Three a Clock.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What time did my Lord of Warwick, and Mr. James, and Mr. Dockwra go away?

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: My Lord of Warwick and they were gone ſeveral hours before Mr. French; and to the beſt of my Remembrance Mr. James broke his Sword upon the Floor after he came in.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, what Swords were there in all that you ſaw there?

sp.speaker: Pomfret.
sp.p: There was Captain French's, Captain James's, my Lord of Warwick's, and one Mr. Coote's, as Mr. French ſaid when it was brought in.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: Have you done with this Witneſs, Mr. Attorney?

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, we have.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: My Lord Warwick, Will you ask him any Queſtions?

sp.speaker: E. of Warwick.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: Then, Mr. Attorney, call your next Witneſs.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Our next Witneſs is Thomas Goodall, who is a Servant at the Bagnio in Longacre, as well as this Man that was laſt.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: What Queſtions do you ask him, Mr. Attorney?

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire he would acquaint your Lordſhips, What time it was my Lord of Warwick, and Capt. French, came to his Maſter's Houſe?

sp.speaker: Goodall.
sp.p: It was between One and two of the Clock in the morning.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire he would acquaint your Lordſhips what he ſaw and knows, that paſſed at that time?

sp.speaker: Goodall.
sp.p: All that I can ſay is, That I did ſee my Lord Warwick's Sword bloody, and it was naked in his Hand, and I did ſee a Wound on his Hand; Indeed I did not ſee him when he firſt came in, for he had been there a pretty while before I ſavv him.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, in vvhat Condition vvas my Lord vvhen you ſavv him?

sp.speaker: Goodall.
sp.p: He had his Svvord in one Hand, and it vvas bloody at the Blade, and at the Hilt, but vvhether it vvas bloody all over indeed I did not take notice of it, and ſo cannot give an account.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, What ſort of Svvord vvas it?

sp.speaker: Goodall.
sp.p: Indeed I cannot give an account what ſort of Sword it was, but it was either Steel or Silver Gilt, as I remember, but I did take notice that there was Blood upon the Hilt, that is, upon the Shell.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Was it an open Shell, or a cloſe one?

sp.speaker: Goodall.
sp.p: I think it was a Cloſe one.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, Did my Lord of Warwick give any Order to be denied in the Houſe, or for any Concealment there?

sp.speaker: Goodall.
sp.p: Indeed I did not hear of any Orders given for Concealing of any body there, but my Lord walked up and down very much Concerned.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did not Mr. French come in with him?

sp.speaker: Goodall.
sp.p: I do believe he might, but I cannot ſay I ſaw him when he came in.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Can you tell when Mr. James and Mr. Dockwra came in, how long was that after my Lord of Warwick was there, and Mr. French?

sp.speaker: Goodall.
sp.p: To the beſt of my remembrance and knowledge, it was half an hour after my Lord of Warwick and Mr. French came, that Mr. James and Mr. Dockwra came, I am ſure it was ſo before I ſaw them in the Houſe, but indeed I cann • t ſay directly when they came in, or when they went out.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, Which Hand of my Lord of Warwick was it that was hurt, the Right or the Left?

sp.speaker: Goodall.
sp.p: Indeed I cannot poſitively ſay, but I think it was the Right Hand.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: You talk of my Lord of Warwick's Sword, Did you take any notice of Mr. French's Sword?

sp.speaker: Goodall.
sp.p: No, indeed, I was buſie about the Affairs of the Houſe, I did ſee my Lord of Warwick's Sword, but that was by chance, and it was bloody at the Hilt, and upon the Blade, but whether it were all over bloody, indeed I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: I deſire to ask him; Whether he can tell who brought in Mr. Coote's Sword thither?

sp.speaker: Goodall.
sp.p: Indeed I cannot.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: Mr. Attorney General, have you any more Queſtions to ask him?

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: No, my Lord, not I.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: My Lord Warwick, Will you ask him any Queſtions?

sp.speaker: E. of Warwick.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: Mr. Attorney, Who is your next Witneſs?

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, our next Witneſs is Mrs. A. Goodall, this Man's Wife.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: What Queſtions do you ask this Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: I deſire that ſhe would acquaint your Lordſhips, Whether ſhe was at the Bagnio in Longacre when my Lord of Warwick and Capt. French came in?

sp.speaker: A. Goodall.
sp.p: I was there when my Lord of Warwick came in.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Was Capt. French with him?

sp.speaker: A. Goodall.
sp.p: Yes, Capt. French was with him.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: About what a Clock was it that they came there?

sp.speaker: A. Goodall.
sp.p: It was about Two a Clock as near as I can remember.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: In what Condition were they when they came in, pray?

sp.speaker: A. Goodall.
sp.p: Mr. French was very much wounded.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, How was my Lord of Warwick?

sp.speaker: A. Goodall.
sp.p: My Lord had his Sword in his Hand, and it was very bloody, both at the Hilt, and upon the Blade.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did you obſerve any Wound that my Lord had?

sp.speaker: A. Goodall.
sp.p: I think, to the beſt of my remembrance, my Lord had his Hand wrapped up in a Handkerchief, which was bloody, but I was buſie up and down in the Houſe, and I cannot ſo well tell what Hand it was, I was indeed up and down there while they were there.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Do you knovv of any Orders that vvere given by my Lord of Warwick to be Concealed vvhile he vvas there?

sp.speaker: A. Goodall.
sp.p: He did deſire the Door might not be opened to any body that asked for him, and that it might not be ſaid that he was there; and when the other Two Gentlemen came to the Door, he went to the Door himſelf, and when he ſaw who they were, he ordered them to be let in.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What was the Occaſion of his going to the Door himſelf?

sp.speaker: A. Goodall.
sp.p: There was a Knocking at the Door, and he had a mind to know who it vvas, and vvhen it did appear it vvas Mr. J • mes and Mr. Dockwra, he himſelf ordered them to be let in.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Hovv came the Door to be open to them?

sp.speaker: A. Goodall.
sp.p: Indeed I think he opened it himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Hovv long vvas that after he and Capt. French came in?

sp.speaker: A. Goodall.
sp.p: It vvas about half an hour.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: When they firſt came in, What poſture vvere they in, had they any Svvords in their Hands?

sp.speaker: A. Goodall.
sp.p: I did not poſitively take notice, vvhether they had any Svvords in their Hands, nor vvhat they had vvhen they came in.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What became of them afterwards?

sp.speaker: A. Goodall.
sp.p: My Lord Warwick, Mr. James, and Mr. Dockwra, went away within a little while, and my Lord of Warwick ordered particular Care to be taken of Mr. French, as his Friend, and he was put to Bed after his Wounds were Dreſſed; but I cannot tell what afterwards became of my Lord Warwick, and the other Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: I think you were ſaying, that my Lord of Warwick was wounded in the Hand, Which Hand was it?

sp.speaker: A. Goodall.
sp.p: I cannot poſitively ſay whether it was the Right or the Left.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: Will you who are of the King's Councel ask this Witneſs any further Queſtions?

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: No, my Lord, we ſhall ask her no other Queſtions.

sp.speaker: E. of Warwick.
sp.p: No, my Lord, nor I.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Then our next Witneſs is Henry Amy, who is a Surgeon, and lives at the Bagnio in Longacre, and he will give your Lordſhip an Account what paſſed within his Knowledge at this time within his Houſe, and who came thither Wounded, and what particular Care was ordered to be taken of Mr. French, and by whom.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: I deſire you will give an Account to my Lords what happened at your Houſe early in the morning the 30th of October laſt?

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: The 30th of October laſt, about Two of the Clock, I was knock't up out of my Bed to Attend two Gentlemen, my Lord Warwick and Capt. French, who came then into my Houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: In what Condition were they?

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: They were both Wounded, Mr. French very much, and my Lord of Warwick in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did you ſee any Swords?

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: Yes, they had both Swords in their Hands, and my Lord of Warwick's Sword was very bloody.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Well, Sir, when they came into your Houſe, What Directions was given by my Lord Warwick?

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: He gave Directions, if any body ſhould ask for him, they ſhould ſay he was not there.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did any body come and ask for him?

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: While we were taking Care of Mr. French, and Dreſſing his Wound, there were ſome Perſons came and knocked at the Door, and my Lord of Warwick did Order, that no body ſhould be let in; but he himſelf went to the Door, and when he found that it was Mr. Dockwra and Mr. James, my Lord Warwick ordered, that they ſhould be let in.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, Tell my Lords what followed after that?

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: After we had Dreſſed Mr. French —

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: By the way, Was there any particular Directions, and by whom, to take Care of Mr. French?

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord Warwick deſired me to take Care of him, as his Particular Friend.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Well then, after you had Dreſſed Mr. Frenche's Wound, what happened?

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: I Dreſſed my Lord Warwick's Wound.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, Whereabouts was my Lord of Warwick's Wound?

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: It was near the firſt Joynt of his Fore-finger.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, How long did they ſtay there?

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: After Mr. Dockwra and Mr. James came in, and my Lord's Hand was Dreſſed, they ſtayed a little while, and they Three went away?

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What was ſaid when they went away?

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: My Lord of Warwick deſired to have great Care taken of Mr. French; and they ſaid, Now let us go away, and they went away.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, What time did they ſtay in your Houſe?

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: When they went away, I think it was about half an hour after they firſt came in.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did you take notice of no Sword but my Lord of Warwick's?

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: No, not then.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did you afterwards?

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: Afterwards, in the morning, Mr. French called for his Sword, and I looked upon it.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, in what Condition was his Sword, was it bloody?

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: It was vvithout Blood, only a little Dirty.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, Did you obſerve that they talked of any Quarrel that had been betvveen Capt. French and my Lord, vvhen they came in?

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did you ask them any Queſtions about it, the one or the other of them?

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did you hear them ſay hovv they came by their Wounds?

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did you hear them talk of any body being killed, particularly Mr. Coote.

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: I did not know of any body being killed till next day.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did you take any notice of James's and Dockwra's Swords?

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: Truly I took no notice of any Swords, but my Lord Warwick's; while my Lord Warwick was there in the Houſe, but the next Morning Mr. French gave me his Sword, and there was another Sword there, which Mr. French told me was Capt. Coote's Sword.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: When was that, How long after my Lord of Warwick, and James, and Dockwra were gone away.

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: It was ſome Hours after.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: When did you hear of Mr. Coote's being killed?

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: About Nine a Clock next Morning I heard of Mr. Coote's being killed.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Whom did you hear it from?

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: From Pomfret my Servant.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did you hear no Diſcourſe between my Lord of Warwick, Capt. French, Mr. James, and Mr. Dockwra about it?

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: No. I did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did they not talk • ow thoſe Wounds came they had, nor did not you ask who gave them?

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: No, I did ask no queſtion of either of them; and in Half an Hour after they came in, my Lord of Warwick and the other Two Gentlemen went away.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: When they left French there, What Orders were left about him?

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: Only to take care of him, my Lord of Warwick deſired that.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What Reaſon did my Lord give for that?

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: I heard nothing of Reaſon, only that he was his particular Friend.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did you hear them talk any thing wither they would go, when they went away.

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: I did hear ſome talk about going into the Country.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Who was it that ſaid that?

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: My Lord of Warwick, when they were going away ſaid, Let us go into the Country.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you know whither they went, when they went away from your Houſe?

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: No, indeed I did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, we have done with him.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: My Lord, Warwick, Will your Lordſhip ask this Witheſs any Queſtions?

sp.speaker: E. of War.
sp.p: I deſire to have him asked whether I was not wounded in the Hand.

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: His Hand was very bloody, the Handkerchief that was about it was wet with the Blood.

sp.speaker: E. of War.
sp.p: I deſire to ask him when it was that he ſaw Capt. French's Sword?

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: It was not before the Morning; it was about Nine a Clock as I remember.

sp.speaker: M. of Norm.
sp.p: Before this Witneſs goes away, I deſire he may be asked one Queſtion, whether he can tell the ſize of Mr. French's Sword.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: Here is a Noble Lord that deſires to know if you can tell about Capt. French's Sword, what ſort of Sword it was.

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: As to the Blade, it was a middle ſiz'd Sword.

sp.speaker: M. of Norm.
sp.p: Was it a broad Blade or no?

sp.speaker: Amy.
sp.p: No, my Lord, it was not a broad Blade.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: Mr. Attorney, Who is your next Witneſs?

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Capt. Loftus Duckingfield.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: This Gentleman will acquaint your Lordſhips what Diſcourſe paſt between theſe Gentlemen the next Day; pray Sir, acquaint my Lords what you heard about Mr. Coote's Death, and when, and where.

sp.speaker: Capt. Duckingfield.
sp.p: Early in the Morning I was told of this Accident.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: By whom?

sp.speaker: Capt. Duck.
sp.p: One of the Company, I cannot tell who, I think they were all together then, my Lord of Warwick, Capt. James, Capt. Dockwra, and no body elſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What was their Diſcourſe?

sp.speaker: Capt. Duck.
sp.p: They ſaid they believed Capt. Coote was killed.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did they tell you by whom?

sp.speaker: Capt. Duck.
sp.p: By Mr. French, every body did ſay he was his Adverſary.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What Account vvas given of the Action?

sp.speaker: Capt. Duck.
sp.p: They ſaid it vvas done in the dark, and Capt. French vvas his Adverſary.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Was there any notice taken of any Duel?

sp.speaker: Capt. Duck.
sp.p: Yes there vvere, betvveen thoſe Tvvo, and the other Perſons on both ſides; and it vvas ſaid my Lord of Warwick vvas Friend to Mr. Coote and my Lord Mohun.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Who were on the other ſide?

sp.speaker: Capt. Duck.
sp.p: Mr. Dockwra and Mr. James.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Were there any Diſcourſe who actually fought?

sp.speaker: Capt. Duck.
sp.p: It was ſaid, that Capt. French fought with Capt. Coote, as they believed, and Mr. James with my Lord of Warwick.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did you ſee my Lord of Warwick's Sword?

sp.speaker: Capt. Duck.
sp.p: Some time of the Day I did, but I cannot tell whether it was in the Morning, or no.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: In what condition was it, Was it bloody, or not!

sp.speaker: Capt. Duck.
sp.p: It was a Stoc • Sword.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: How long did they ſtay with you?

sp.speaker: Capt. Duck.
sp.p: About Half an Hour.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did they come publickly?

sp.speaker: Capt. Duck.
sp.p: We went away in a Hackney Coach together.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: • ray what Diſcourſe were there about conſulting to go into the Countrey together?

sp.speaker: Capt. Duck.
sp.p: That might be Diſcourſed but by whom I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did my Lord of Warwick talk of going into the Countrey?

sp.speaker: Capt. Duck.
sp.p: Whether the Company talked of it, or my Lord of Warwick in particular, and the reſt aſſented to it, I cannot well tell.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Whither did they go?

sp.speaker: Capt. Duck.
sp.p: I cannot directly tell.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What time of the Day was it?

sp.speaker: Capt. Duck.
sp.p: It was about Six of the Clock.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Cannot you tell wither they went?

sp.speaker: Capt. Duck.
sp.p: Capt. James and Capt. Dockwra went to the Sh • p and Caſ • le in Cornhill about Five a Clock or Six, as near as I can remember.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Can you tell what time my Lord of Warwick, went away.?

sp.speaker: Capt. Duck.
sp.p: No, I cannot tell what time he went away, not directly.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Can you tell of any Agreement amongſt them, whither they were to go?

sp.speaker: Capt. Duck.
sp.p: No, I cannot.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What Diſcourſe or Concern did you obſerve paſt between them concerning Capt. Coote?

sp.speaker: Capt. Duck.
sp.p: My Lord of Warwick ſhewed a great deal of Concern for his Friend Mr. Coote.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Had you any notice of Mr. Coote's Death amongſt you?

sp.speaker: Capt. Duck.
sp.p: We had notice before we went away, but I cannot tell whether it was before my Lord of Warwick was gone.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Was it after the Diſcourſe of going into the Country, or before?

sp.speaker: Capt. Duck.
sp.p: Indeed I cannot directly ſay when it was.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray what reaſon was there for their going into the Country before he was dead?

sp.speaker: Capt. Duck.
sp.p: They believed he was dead.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Cannot you tell the reaſon why they would go into the Country?

sp.speaker: Capt. Duck.
sp.p: No indeed, I cannot tell the reaſon.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did you obſerve my Lord of Warwick's Sword? Was there any Blood upon it?

sp.speaker: Capt. Duck.
sp.p: I cannot ſay his Sword was bloody at the point; the whole Blade and Shell was bloody, to the beſt of my remembrance.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What ſort of Sword was it?

sp.speaker: Capt. Duck.
sp.p: It was a pretty broad Blade, a hollow Blade, and a hollow open Shell.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Was there any Diſcourſe concerning Capt. French?

sp.speaker: Capt. Duck.
sp.p: Yes, they thought he was very ill wounded.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Was there any, and what Diſcourſe who ſhould give my Lord of Warwick his Wound?

sp.speaker: Capt. Duck.
sp.p: It was ſaid, they believed Capt. James gave my Lord his wound.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray was there any Blood upon Mr. James's Sword, or was he wounded?

sp.speaker: Capt. Duck.
sp.p: I ſaw no wound upon Capt. James, that I know of.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: Do you believe that my Lord Warwick's Sword was bloodied with the hurt of his own Hand, or any otherwiſe?

sp.speaker: Capt. Duck.
sp.p: I cannot tell, it was a Cut Shell, and the outſide bloody as well as the in.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: My Lord Warwick, Will your Lordſhip ask this Witneſs any Queſtions?

sp.speaker: E. of War,
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: Mr. Attorney, if you have any other Witneſſes, pray call them.

div.stage: Another Witneſs was produced, that belonged to the Ship and Caſtle in Cornhill.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: This Man will give you an Account what paſt at his Houſe at that time, and between whom; Pray will you tell my Lords who was at your Houſe the 30th. of October laſt, and what paſt there then.

sp.speaker: Witneſs.
sp.p: My Lord of Warwick, Capt. James and Capt. Dockwra, and when my Lord of Warwick came in, I thought my Lord was in a very great Concern, and called for Pen, Ink and Paper, and I fear'd there was ſome quarrel in hand, but they ſaid no, the Quarrel was over, and ſays, my Lord of Warwick, I am afraid poor Coote is killed.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did you obſerve any deſire to be private?

sp.speaker: Witneſs.
sp.p: No indeed, I cannot tell that.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: How long did they continue there?

sp.speaker: Witneſs.
sp.p: About 6 a Clock my Lord of Warwick and Capt. James, and Capt. Dockwra, and Capt. Ducking field went away.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Can you tell who went with my Lord Warwick?

sp.speaker: Witneſs.
sp.p: No indeed, I cannot tell who went with my Lord Warwick; there came in a Gentleman in Black, whom I knew to be my Lord of Warwick's Steward, and he came and ſpoke ſome words to my Lord of Warwick, about a quarter of an Hour after they came in, and then they went away, for after that I did not hear any farther Diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What became of the reſt of the Company?

sp.speaker: Witneſs.
sp.p: They went away; I do not know what became of them, nor whether they went; ſome of them went in and out of one Room into another ſeveral times, two or three times, and came out again.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, we have done with this Witneſs.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: My Lord Warwick, will you ask him any Queſtions?

sp.speaker: E. of Warw.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: Mr. Attorney, who is your next Witneſs?

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Mr. Salmon the Chirurgeon, who by the Coroner's Order ſearched the Wound.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, was you ordered by the Coroner to view the Body of Mr. Coote?

sp.speaker: Salm.
sp.p: Yes, I was ordered by the Coroner to inſpect the Body of Captain Coote, and to give the Jury an account of the nature of the Wounds.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray upon the view of the Body, what Wounds had he?

sp.speaker: Salm.
sp.p: There was two Wounds; one on the Breaſt near the Collar-bone running downwards very deep.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray what part of the Breaſt was it, and how deep was it?

sp.speaker: Salm.
sp.p: It was on the left part of the Breaſt near the Collar-bone, and it penetrated four or five Inches.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Can you gueſs at what ſort of Sword it was that made the Wound?

sp.speaker: Salm.
sp.p: No indeed, Sir, I cannot.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Was it a broad Sword, or a little Sword?

sp.speaker: Salm.
sp.p: The Orifice was about the length of half an Inch, and about the depth of five Inches.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Was that made with a broad Sword, or with a narrow Sword?

sp.speaker: Salm.
sp.p: Indeed I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: You ſay he had another Wound; where was that?

sp.speaker: Salm.
sp.p: That was on his left Side too, near unto the ſhort Ribs, under the laſt Rib, which was about the length of an Inch, and of the depth of ſix Inches, and it run through the Diaphragma.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Did you take one of thoſe Wounds, or both of them to be mortal?

sp.speaker: Salm.
sp.p: I did look upon either of them to be mortal, and to be the occaſion of his death.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Can you tell whether they were both made with one and the ſame Sword?

sp.speaker: Salm.
sp.p: Indeed I cannot tell that, whether they were made with one Sword, or two.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Cannot you tell how they appeared to be? I ſuppoſe you probed them.

sp.speaker: Salm.
sp.p: Yes, I probed them both; one was quite through the Diaphragma.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What time was it that you viewed the Body by the Order of the Coroner?

sp.speaker: Salm.
sp.p: I ſaw the Body at Seven a Clock on Sunday night.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: If my Lord of Warwick deſire to ask him any Queſtions, he may.

sp.speaker: E. of Warw.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire to ask him, whether any of the Wounds were large enough to be made by a Sword run up to the Hilt?

sp.speaker: Salm.
sp.p: No, my Lord, ſure that they were not.

sp.speaker: E. of Warw.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſi • e to know of him, whether both thoſe Wounds were given before or behind?

sp.speaker: Salm.
sp.p: I can only tell you the length and depth by following of the Probe; the one was downwards, and the other upwards.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Do you ſuppoſe both thoſe Wounds were given when the Perſon was ſtanding backward or forward?

sp.speaker: Salm.
sp.p: 'Tis impoſſible to tell how they were given, becauſe of the variety of the Poſtures of the Body in the divers Capacities thereby of receiving the Wounds?

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray can you tell whether they were given by one and the ſame Sword or no?

sp.speaker: Salm.
sp.p: Indeed I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Do you know any thing to the contrary?

sp.speaker: Salm.
sp.p: I cannot ſay any thing for it, or againſt it.

sp.speaker: E. of Kingſton.
sp.p: My Lords, this Witneſs, if I apprehend him right, ſays, the Wound on his Side was a large Wound.

sp.speaker: Salm.
sp.p: Yes, a very large Wound, of the length of about three quarters of an Inch at the Orifice, and five or ſix Inches deep.

sp.speaker: E. of Kingſton.
sp.p: I deſire he may tell whether that Wound could be given by any other than a broad Sword.

sp.speaker: Salm.
sp.p: I cannot tell that.

sp.speaker: E. of Rocheſter.
sp.p: Indeed, my Lords, I would have him asked this Queſtion again; I know not whether he can anſwer it or no; but I cannot but think it is proper to have ſome account of this matter. In all Enquiries before the Coroner, there is a Judgment to be made of the Nature of the Wound, in order to form the Indictments, and that the Jury may know with what ſort of Weapon it was made; and it is his Profeſſion, as a Chirurgeon, to know ſuch matters.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: Mr. Salmon, you hear what is required of you by my Noble Lords, and the Obſervation which is made. You are the Chirurgeon ſent for by the Coroner, on purpoſe to inſpect this Body; and when you did ſo, it was incumbent upon you to conſider and give information, as well with what ſort of Inſtrument the Wound was given, as the length and depth of the Wound, that the Jury might conſider upon all the Circumſtances of the Occaſion, and Manner of the Party's Death: And my Lords would know whether by the Orifices of the Wounds when you inſpected them, you can make a Judgment if they were made by ſeveral Swords, or the ſame Sword.

sp.speaker: Salm.
sp.p: I cannot ſay that I ſaw any difference between the Orifices, as to the nature of the Inſtrument they were given with, nor whether they were made by one and the ſame Sword or no, only the one Orifice was bigger than the other; that of the Side was bigger than that at the Collar-bone.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: Then ſo far we have light (if I apprehend you rightly) the Orifice of the upper Wound was not near ſo wide as that of the lower; but it ſeems to be much in one of your Profeſſion not to be able to judge whether the Wounds were given with the ſame ſort of Sword, when there was ſuch a difference in the Orifice.

sp.speaker: Salm.
sp.p: That below was a deeper Wound; and there was a conſiderable difference between the largeneſs of the one and the other.

sp.speaker: Ld. Audley.
sp.p: My Lords, I deſire he may tell your Lordſhips how far backward the Wound in the Side lay.

sp.speaker: Salm.
sp.p: It was directly on the left Side, immediately under the two laſt Ribs, and paſt through the Diaphragma.

sp.speaker: M. of Normanby.
sp.p: Pray, my Lords, let him point with his Finger whereabouts it was.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: My Lords would have you ſhow them with your Finger whereabouts it was.

sp.speaker: E. of Warw.
sp.p: It is a very material Queſtion for me that he ſhould anſwer, whether he did believe that one and the ſame Sword might not give both Wounds?

sp.speaker: Salm.
sp.p: I cannot ſay any thing of it one way or other; but one Wound went much further than the other, becauſe it was in a fleſhy part; and in ſuch a caſe, the further a Sword goes in, it makes the Wound larger.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Then our next Witneſs is Stephen Turner, who was Mr Coote's Man, and he will give you an account what Sword his Maſter had, and where he found it.

stage.hi: He was Sworn, 〈◊〉 Sword was ſhewn him.

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: This was my Maſter's Sword Mr. Coote's, and I never ſaw it after he went out in the morning till I ſaw it in the hands of the Conſtable, and afterwards before the Coroner.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: What time did you hear of your Maſter's death?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: It was about nine a Clock next morning that I heard he was dead.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Where was your Maſter's Body?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: It was in St. Martins-Lane.

sp.speaker: E. of Tanckerville.
sp.p: I would deſire he might be asked one Queſtion, whether his Maſter uſed his left Hand or his right?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: I do believe he was a right-handed Man; I did never ſee him Fence. It was on the Sonday morning that I went to the Round-houſe, where I found my Maſter dead.

sp.speaker: E. of Warw.
sp.p: I deſire he may be asked whether he has not obſerved a particular Kindneſs and Friendſhip between his Maſter and me?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord; I have ſeveral times waited upon my Maſter, when my Lord and he was together, and they were always very civil and kind one to another, and I never heard one Word of any Unkindneſs between them.

sp.speaker: E. of Warw.
sp.p: Whether he knows of any Quarrel that was between us?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: No, I never did.

sp.speaker: E. of Warw.
sp.p: I deſire he may be asked, whether he did not uſe to lie at my Lodgings ſometimes?

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: You hear my Lord's Queſtion; what ſay you, did your Maſter uſe to lie at my Lord of Warwick's Lodgings at any time?

sp.speaker: Turn.
sp.p: Yes, very often.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Pray call Pomfret again, and let him ſee the Sword.

div.stage: Then he came in, and two Swords were ſhewn him.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: I deſire he may acquaint your Lordſhips what he knows of thoſe two Swords.

sp.speaker: Pomf.
sp.p: Theſe two Swords were brought in by ſome of the Company that came to my Maſter's Houſe, and when they were ſhewn to Capt. French in the morning, he owned this to be his, and the other to be Mr. Coote's; and he deſired that notice might be taken that his Sword was dirty, but not bloody, and there was ſome Blood upon the other.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Who brought in Mr. Coote's Sword?

sp.speaker: Pomf.
sp.p: Indeed I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: Then our laſt piece of Evidence, my Lord, will be that of Mr. White the Coroner.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: What do you ask him, Mr. Attorney?

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: From whom had he theſe Swords?

sp.speaker: White.
sp.p: May it pleaſe your Grace, theſe Swords were delivered to me by the Conſtable.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire he may be asked, whether upon his view of the Body he looked upon the Wounds, and whether he did apprehend they were given by one and the ſame Sword?

sp.speaker: White.
sp.p:
May it pleaſe your Grace, when I had Sworn my Inqueſt, I ſent for the Chirurgeon that was here before, and gave him order to probe the Wounds, that the Jury might know the nature of them, in order to the drawing up the Inquiſition, and I did expreſly ask him, Whether he found any ſuch diſtinction between them, that they were given by one and the ſame Weapon, or different Weapons? He ſaid as he ſays now, That he could not tell whether the Wounds were given by two Swords, or by one; but he did apprehend there was a great difference between them, and ſo did I; but generally the Orifice of a Wound does cloſe up when the Body is
Gold; one of the Wounds were nearer the left Side than the other, to the beſt of my remembrance it was almoſt behind him.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: We have done with our Evidence, until we hear what my Lord of Warwick ſays to it.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: My Lord Warwick, will you ask this Witneſs any queſtions?

sp.speaker: E. of War.
sp.p: No my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: Make Proclamation for Silence.

sp.speaker: Cl. of the Crown.
sp.p: Serjeant at Arms, make Proclamation.

sp.speaker: Ser. at Arms.
sp.p: O yes, O yes, O yes. His Grace, my Lord High-Steward of England does Strictly Charge and Command all manner of Perſons here preſent, to keep Silence, upon pain of Impriſonment.

sp.speaker: L. H. St.
sp.p: My Lord of Warwick, the Kings Councell have made an end of giving Evidence for the King; now is the proper time for you to enter upon your Defence.

sp.speaker: E. of Warw.
sp.p: May it pleaſe your Grace, and you my Noble Lords, my Peers.

I ſtand here before Your Lordſhips accuſed of the Murther of Mr. Coote, of which I am ſo Innocent, that I came and voluntarily Surrendred my ſelf ſo ſoon as I heard your Lordſhips might be at leiſure to Try me; and had ſooner done it, but that the King was not then here, nor your Lordſhips Sitting, and had no mind to undergo a long Confinement; and now I think I might well Submit it to your Lordſhips Judgment, even on the Evidence has been offered againſt me, whether there hath been any thing proved of Malice Prepenſe, or my being any Actor therein, ſo as to adjudge me Guilty: And I think I may with humble Submiſſion to your Lordſhips ſay, that my Innocence appeareth even from ſeveral of the Witneſſes who have been examined againſt me, which I will not trouble your Lordſhips to Repeat, but ſubmit to your Memory and Obſervation.

But my Lords, the Safety of my Life does not ſo much concern me in this Caſe, as the vindication of my Honour and Reputation, from the falſe Reflections to which the Proſecutor has endeavoured to expoſe me, and I ſhall therefore beg your Lordſhips patience to give a fair and full account of this matter; In which the Duty I owe to your Lordſhips, and to Juſtice in general, and the right I owe to my own Cauſe in particular, do ſo oblige me, that I will not in the leaſt prevaricate, neither will I conceal or deny any thing that is true.

My Lords, I muſt confeſs I was there when this unfortunate Accident happened, which muſt be a great misfortune in any Caſe, but was more ſo to me in this, becauſe Mr. Coote was my particular Friend, and I did all I could to hinder it, as your Lordſhips may obſerve by the whole proceedings.
